standard_metadata.standard_description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Positive and negative linear associations from scatter plots

question.content: The plot shown below describes the relationship between the average income in a city and the average rent for a $1$-bedroom apartment in that city.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Average rent for a 1 bedroom, in dollars per month, from 0 to 2000, in increments of 100, on the y-axis, versus Average income, in dollars per year, from 30000 to 50000, in increments of 5000, on the x-axis. 17 points rise diagonally in a loose cluster between (36500, 825) and (58500, 1800). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Average rent for a 1 bedroom, in dollars per month, from 0 to 2000, in increments of 100, on the y-axis, versus Average income, in dollars per year, from 30000 to 50000, in increments of 5000, on the x-axis. 17 points rise diagonally in a loose cluster between (36500, 825) and (58500, 1800). A regression line rises diagonally through the center of the cluster from (33000, 0) to (60000, 1650). All values estimated.

hints.content: The line we drew through the data has a positive slope, so this scatter plot shows a positive linear association.
The answer:  Positive linear association

question.content: The graph shown below shows the relationship between the age of drivers and the number of car accidents per $100$ drivers in the year $2009$.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Accidents per 100 drivers, from 9 to 24, in increments of 1, on the y-axis, versus Age, in years, from 16 to 25, in increments of 0.5, on the x-axis. 9 points fall diagonally in a loose, but narrow cluster between (16, 23) and (24, 11). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Accidents per 100 drivers, from 9 to 24, in increments of 1, on the y-axis, versus Age, in years, from 16 to 25, in increments of 0.5, on the x-axis. 9 points fall diagonally in a loose, but narrow cluster between (16, 23) and (24, 11). A regression line falls through the center of the points from (0, 22) to (25, 10.9). All values estimated.

hints.content: The line we drew through the data has a negative slope, so this scatter plot shows a negative linear association.
The answer:  Negative linear association

question.content: Vincent gathered groups of $1$ to $8$ people and gave every group the same puzzle to solve. He recorded the number of minutes it took each group to solve the puzzle and plotted the results.     **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Time, in minutes, from 0 to 20, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Group size, from 0 to 8, in increments of 1, on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow curved pattern, with decreasing steepness, between (1, 20) and (8, 6.5). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.

images.alt: A graph plots Time, in minutes, from 0 to 20, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Group size, from 0 to 8, in increments of 1, on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow curved pattern, with decreasing steepness, between (1, 20) and (8, 6.5). A regression line falls from (0, 14) to (10, 2.5). All values estimated.

hints.content: Might a curve fit the data better than a line?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Time, in minutes, from 0 to 20, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Group size, from 0 to 8, in increments of 1, on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow curved pattern, with decreasing steepness, between (1, 20) and (8, 6.5). A regression curve falls with decreasing steepness through (1, 17), (2, 10), and (7.5, 6). All values estimated.

hints.content: The answer:  Nonlinear association

question.content: Aubree wanted to see if there is a connection between the time a given exam takes place and the average score of this exam.  She collected data about all the exams from the previous year and arranged the average scores of the exams according to the period they took place, as shown below.     **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Average score, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Period, from 0 to 9, in increments of 0.5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points extend nearly horizontally rightward, in a loose, wide cluster with points plotted between x = 1 and x = 8, and between y = 39 and y = 78.  All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
No. Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.
It would also be impossible to draw a curve that fit the data very well.
The answer:  No association

question.content: The graph below shows the relationship between population density and pollution per person for $36$ Japanese cities.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots C O 2 emissions per person, in metric tons, from 0 to 25, in increments of 1, on the y-axis, versus People, per square kilometer, from 0 to 3500, in increments of 500, on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points are scattered sporadically between x = 350 and x = 3450, and between y = 3.5 and y = 22. Points are highly concentrated near the lower left of the graph. All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
No. Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.
It would also be impossible to draw a curve that fit the data very well.
The answer:  No association

question.content: An international cake competition attracted $50$ bakers from around the world. The graph below shows the relationship between the amount of sugar in the cakes (in grams per $100$ grams of cake) and the scores the cakes received.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Score, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Grams of sugar, per 100 grams of cake, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points create an upside-down U-shape, which rises from (1, 7) with decreasing steepness through a heavily concentrated vertex near (20, 95) before falling with increasing steepness to (37, 18). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.

images.alt: A graph plots Score, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Grams of sugar, per 100 grams of cake, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points create an upside-down U-shape, which rises from (1, 7) with decreasing steepness through a heavily concentrated vertex near (20, 95) before falling with increasing steepness to (37, 18). 3 regression lines are also provided. The first rises from (0, 20) to (18, 105). The second rises from (0, 60) to (26, 105). The third falls from (22, 105) to (40, 20). All values estimated.

hints.content: Might a curve fit the data better than a line?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Score, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Grams of sugar, per 100 grams of cake, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points create an upside-down U-shape, which rises from (1, 7) with decreasing steepness through a heavily concentrated vertex near (20, 95) before falling with increasing steepness to (37, 18). A regression curve rises throuhg the center of the cluster from (0, 0) with decreasing steepness through the vertex at (20, 92.5) before falling with increasing steepness to (40, 0). All values estimated.

hints.content: The answer:  Nonlinear association

question.content: The graph shown below describes the change in the average temperature of the world over time.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Degrees above 13, in degrees Celsius, from 0 to 2, in increments of 0.1, on the y-axis, versus Years since 1970, from 0 to 45, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points rise in a tight, narrow pattern, between (0, 1.1) and (42, 1.6). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Degrees above 13, in degrees Celsius, from 0 to 2, in increments of 0.1, on the y-axis, versus Years since 1970, from 0 to 45, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points rise in a tight, narrow pattern, between (0, 1.1) and (42, 1.6). A regression line rises through the center of the cluster from (0, 0.95) to (45, 1.7). All values estimated.

hints.content: The line we drew through the data has a positive slope, so this scatter plot shows a positive linear association.
The answer:  Positive linear association

question.content: The graph shown below shows the relationship between average heart rate (in beats per minute) of several mammal species and their life expectancy (in years).    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Life expectancy, in years, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Heart rate, in beats per minute, from 0 to 600, in increments of 50 on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow, tightly clustered, curved pattern with decreasing steepness, between (40, 40) and (600, 4). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.

images.alt: A graph plots Life expectancy, in years, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Heart rate, in beats per minute, from 0 to 600, in increments of 50 on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow, tightly clustered, curved pattern with decreasing steepness, between (40, 40) and (600, 4). A regression line falls through the points from (0, 23) to (525, 0). All values estimated.

hints.content: Might a curve fit the data better than a line?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Life expectancy, in years, from 0 to 40, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Heart rate, in beats per minute, from 0 to 600, in increments of 50 on the x-axis. Approximately 2 dozen points fall in a narrow, tightly clustered, curved pattern with decreasing steepness, between (40, 40) and (600, 4). A regression curve falls with decreasing steepness away from the y-axis, through (10, 35), (225, 10), and (550, 2). All values estimated.

hints.content: The answer:  Nonlinear association

question.content: The graph below shows the relationship between life expectancy and infant mortality in a random sample of countries.    **What is the best description of this relationship?**

images.alt: A graph plots Life expectancy, in years, from 0 to 85, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Infant mortality, per 1000, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points fall diagonally in a tight, narrow cluster, between (1, 83) and (75, 42). The cluster is more highly concentrated leftward of x = 20 and less concentrated rightward of x = 20. All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph plots Life expectancy, in years, from 0 to 85, in increments of 5, on the y-axis, versus Infant mortality, per 1000, from 0 to 100, in increments of 5, on the x-axis. Dozens of points fall diagonally in a tight, narrow cluster, between (1, 83) and (75, 42). The cluster is more highly concentrated leftward of x = 20 and less concentrated rightward of x = 20. A regression line falls through the center of the cluster from (0, 80) to (100, 35). All values estimated.

hints.content: The line we drew through the data has a negative slope, so this scatter plot shows a negative linear association.
The answer:  Negative linear association

question.content: **What is the best description of the relationship in the scatterplot below?**

images.alt: A graph has an x-axis which ranges from 0 to 14, in increments of 2, and a y-axis which ranges from negative 6 to 6, in increments of 2. Dozens of points form an upward opening parabola. Points fall in a tight, narrow, curve from (0, 4.5) with decreasing steepness through its vertex, (5, negative 4) which also has the highest concentration of points, before rising with increasing steepness to (10, 5). All values estimated.

hints.content: Can you picture a line going through the data?
Any line we might draw wouldn't fit the data very well.

images.alt: A graph has an x-axis which ranges from 0 to 14, in increments of 2, and a y-axis which ranges from negative 6 to 6, in increments of 2. Dozens of points form an upward opening parabola. Points fall in a tight, narrow, curve from (0, 4.5) with decreasing steepness through its vertex, (5, negative 4) which also has the highest concentration of points, before rising with increasing steepness to (10, 5). There are 3 lines of regression. The first falls through the cluster from (0, 3.2) to (6, negative 6.2). The second extends horizontally between (2, negative 3) and (8, negative 3). The third rises through the cluster from (4, negative 6.1) to (10, 4). All values estimated.

hints.content: Might a curve fit the data better than a line?
Yes. Here's what it might look like:

images.alt: A graph has an x-axis which ranges from 0 to 14, in increments of 2, and a y-axis which ranges from negative 6 to 6, in increments of 2. Dozens of points form an upward opening parabola. Points fall in a tight, narrow, curve from (0, 4.5) with decreasing steepness through its vertex, (5, negative 4) which also has the highest concentration of points, before rising with increasing steepness to (10, 5). A regression curve follows the shape of the parabola, which falls from (0, 4.3) with decreasing steepness through the vertex at (4.9, negative 3) before rising through (9, 3). All values estimated.

hints.content: The answer:  Nonlinear association
